newsitem.title: DENMARK: Danish bond prices struck by Greenspan jitters.
newsitem.headline: Danish bond prices struck by Greenspan jitters.

text.p: Danish bond prices remained depressed on Wednesday as the market nervously awaited the second phase of U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's congressional testimony, due at 1900 GMT.
"It looks like being a hesitant market until Greenspan's speech this evening," a dealer said.
At 1235 GMT the benchmark eight percent state bond due 2006 was down 0.45 point from Tuesday's close to 111.56, yielding 6.28 percent. Its March future fell 0.54 point to 111.38.
The six percent mortgage bond due 2026 lost 0.25 point, falling to 89.75.
The crown traded at 3.8137 per mark, firming slightly from 3.8140 late on Tuesday.

The 10-year yield gap with Germany narrowed to 68 basis points from Tuesday's 69 bp. Dealers cited Wednesday's better than expected trade and current acount data and Denmark's position outside current worries about the timetable for EMU.
Danes voted in a binding 1993 referendum not to join the single currency.
"If we can avoid fresh upset the yield gap could go toward 63 basis points," a dealer said. --Steve Weizman, Copenhagen newsroom, 45-33-969650
